questions.text: Which vasoactive peptide is not produced by carcinoid tumour?
questions.solution:
Carcinoid tumours

  • These neuroendocrine tumours occur throughout the gastrointestinal tract, most commonly in the appendix, ileum and rectum in decreasing order of frequency.
  • Appendicular carcinoid tumours are commonly noted as an incidental finding at appendicectomy, and are said to occur in approximately 2% of appendices removed surgically.
  • The tumour arises from Kulchitsky cells at the base of intestinal crypts (of Lieberkuhn).
  • Carcinoid tumours can produce a number of vasoactive peptides, most commonly 5-hydroxytryptamine (serotonin), but also histamine, prostaglandins and kallikrein.
  • Plasma markers of tumour bulk, such as chromogranin A concentrations, may be useful markers of disease recurrence, as well as of prognostic value.

CARCINOID TUMOR OF THE SMALL INTESTINE

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 74, Edition: 28th, Pg: 1310

questions.text: Which among the following is not included in the Rigler's triad?
questions.solution:
Gallstones

  • This type of obstruction tends to occur in the elderly secondary to erosion of a large gallstone directly through the gall bladder into the duodenum.
  • Classically, there is impaction about 60 cm proximal to the ileocaecal valve.
  • The patient may have recurrent attacks as the obstruction is frequently incomplete or relapsing as a result of a ball-valve effect.
  • The characteristic radiological sign of gallstone ileus is Rigler’s triad, comprising: small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia and an atypical mineral shadow on radiographs of the abdomen.
  • The presence of two of these radiological signs has been considered pathognomic of gallstone ileus and is encountered in 40-50% of the cases (note than pneumobilia is common following endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with sphincterotomy).
  • At laparotomy, the stone is milked proximally away from the site of impaction.
  • It may be possible to crush the stone within the bowel lumen; if not, the intestine is opened at this point and the gallstone removed. If the gallstone is faceted, a careful check for other enteric stones should be made. The region of the gall bladder should not be explored.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 78, Edition: 28th, Pg: 1377

questions.text: Which among the following is not the clinical presentation of familial adenomatous polyposis?
questions.solution:
• Clinically, FAP is characterized by early development of a wide range of colorectal adenomatous polyps after the second decade of life and many extracolonic manifestations.
  • Patients with FAP may be asymptomatic or may present with bleeding, diarrhoea, abdominal pain, or mucous discharge per rectum. Other symptoms such as anaemia, obstruction, or weight loss usually occur as polyps grow larger in size or number and may foreshadow the presence of cancer.
  • A variety of benign and malignant extracolonic manifestations have been described in FAP.
  • These include gastroduodenal adenomas and carcinoma, desmoids, osteomas, epidermoid cysts, papillary thyroid carcinoma, small bowel polyps and carcinoma, congenital hyperplasia of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE), and dental anomalies.

Reference: Sabiston textbook of Surgery, chapter: 52, Edition: 21st, Pg: 1368

questions.text: Which is the gold standard test for the diagnosis of Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Endoscopy.

  • Ileocolonoscopy with biopsies of the terminal ileum are the gold standard for the diagnosis of Crohn disease.
  • When the colon is involved, sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy may reveal characteristic aphthous ulcers with granularity and a normal-appearing surrounding
  • Intubation of the ileocecal valve during colonoscopy allows examination and biopsy of the terminal ileum but fails to evaluate other segments of the small
  • With more progressive and severe disease, the ulcerations involve progressively more of the bowel lumen, and it may be difficult to distinguish Crohn disease from ulcerative
  • However, the presence of discrete ulcers and cobblestoning as well as the discontinuous segments of involved bowel favors a diagnosis of Crohn
  • Endoscopic advances that allow better evaluation of the small intestine include singleballoon enteroscopy, double-balloon enteroscopy, and spiral enteroscopy; the most well-established technique is doubleballoon enteroscopy, which allows increased enteral intubation (240-360 cm) compared with push enteroscopy (90-150 cm) or ileocolonoscopy (50-80 cm).
  • Limitations include specialized examiner skills and equipment, prolonged procedure times, and a 1% risk of complications (e.g., pancreatitis, perforation, or bleeding).
  • After the diagnosis is confirmed, the Crohn Disease Endoscopic Index of Severity (CDEIS) or the Simple Endoscopic Score for Crohn Disease (SES-CD) is used to define extent of disease and severity.

Reference: Sabiston textbook of Surgery, chapter: 50, Edition: 21st, Pg: 1264

questions.text: Which of the following symptom is not included in murphy's triad?
questions.solution:
Murphy's triad include

  1. Abdominal pain
  2. Vomiting
  3. Fever

The classical features of acute appendicitis begin with poorly localised colicky abdominal pain.

This is due to mid-gut visceral discomfort in response to appendiceal inflammation and obstruction.

The pain is frequently first noticed in the periumbilical region and is similar to, but less intense than, the colic of small bowel obstruction. Central abdominal pain is associated with anorexia, nausea and usually one or two episodes of vomiting that follow the onset of pain (Murphy).

Anorexia is a useful and constant clinical feature, particularly in children. The patient often gives a history of similar discomfort that settled spontaneously. A family history is also useful as up to one-third of children with appendicitis have a first-degree relative with a similar history.

With progressive inflammation of the appendix, the parietal peritoneum in the right iliac fossa becomes irritated, producing more intense, constant and localised somatic pain that begins to predominate.

Patients often report this as an abdominal pain that has shifted and changed in character. Typically, coughing or sudden movement exacerbates the right iliac fossa pain.

During the first 6 hours, there is rarely any alteration in temperature or pulse rate. After that time, slight pyrexia (37.2-37.7°C) with a corresponding increase in the pulse rate to 80 or 90 is usual.

In children, a temperature greater than 38.5°C suggests other causes (e.g. mesenteric adenitis [see below]).

Typically, two clinical syndromes of acute appendicitis can be discerned, acute catarrhal (non-obstructive) appendicitis and acute obstructive appendicitis, the latter characterised by a more acute course.

The onset of symptoms is abrupt and there may be generalised abdominal pain from the start. The temperature may be normal and vomiting is common, so the clinical picture may mimic acute intestinal obstruction.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter 76, Edition 28th, Pg: 1338

questions.text: Label the diagram correctly for fistula in ano according to park's classification:
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter 80, Edition 28th, Pg: 1436

questions.text: What is the preferred timing of early cholecystectomy after the attack of acute cholecystitis?
questions.solution:
• Patients who present with acute cholecystitis should receive IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and analgesia.
  • The antibiotics should cover gram-negative enteric organisms as well as anaerobes.
  • Although the inflammation in acute cholecystitis may be sterile in some patients, it is difficult to know who is secondarily infected.
  • Therefore, antibiotics have become a standard part of the initial management of acutecholecystitis in most centers.
  • Cholecystectomy is the definitive treatment for acute cholecystitis.
  • In the past, the timing of cholecystectomy has been a matter of debate. Earlycholecystectomy performed within 72 hours of the onset of the illness is preferred over delayed cholecystectomy that is performed 6 to 10 weeks after initialmedical treatment and recuperation.
  • Several studies have shown that unless the patient is unfit for surgery, early cholecystectomy should be recommended as soon as possible, as it offers the patient a definitive solution in one hospital admission, quicker recovery times, similar complication rates, and an earlier return to work.

Reference: Schwartz's Principles of Surgery 11th edition, Chapter 32, Gallbladder and the Extrahepatic Biliary System, pg no: 1406.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a systemic complication of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 72, The Pancreas Pg: 1274.

questions.text: Which is the best modality of investigation in a case of a small ampullary tumour of pancreas?
questions.solution:
The preferred test to identify a tumour in the head of the pancreas is a contrast-enhanced CT scan.

But small ampullary lesions may not be seen on CT, and ERCP is the best way to identify them.

The prothrombin time should be checked, and clotting abnormalities should be corrected with vitamin K or fresh-frozen plasma prior to ERCP.

Ampullary tumour of Pancreas

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, 27th Edition, Chapter 68, The Pancreas, Pg: 1235.

questions.text: Identify the procedure in the given diagram
questions.solution:
Puestow's procedure

Reference: Schwartz's Principles of Surgery 11th edition, Chapter, Chapter 33, Pancreas. Pg: 1473

questions.text: Which is the best modality of investigation in a case of a small ampullary tumour of pancreas?
questions.solution:
The preferred test to identify a tumour in the head of the pancreas is a contrast-enhanced CT scan.

But small ampullary lesions may not be seen on CT, and ERCP is the best way to identify them.

The prothrombin time should be checked, and clotting abnormalities should be corrected with vitamin K or fresh-frozen plasma prior to ERCP.

Ampullary tumour of Pancreas

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, 27th Edition, Chapter 68, The Pancreas, Pg: 1235.

choices.text: Endoscopic sclerotherapy increases portal venous pressure
Upper GI endoscopy must be performed only after 12 hours of admission
Band ligation is the preferred endoscopic method in control of variceal bleeding
Patient should be stated on vasoactive drugs early to control haemorrhage

questions.text: Which among the following statements is not true in the management of oesophageal varices?
questions.solution:
Early upper GI endoscopy, preferably within 12 hours of admission should be done to identify the source of the bleed.

Treatment of oesophageal varices -

  • Resuscitation and stabilisation of the patient with IV fluids, airway protection and oxygen.
  • Consider blood transfusion if haemoglobin falls below 7gm/dl.
  • Start the patient on vasopressins, octreotide to control bleeding. Octreotide is believed to be as effective as endoscopic therapy in controlling bleeding.
  • Early upper GI endoscopy, preferably within 12 hours of admission should be done to identify the source of the bleed.
  • Because infections are common in patients with variceal bleeding, antibiotic prophylaxis should be initiated
  • Endoscopic band ligation or sclerotherapy. Band ligation is preferred over sclerotherapy as it has fewer complications. Sclerotherapy, but not band ligation, may increase portal pressures.
  • If they fail - Consider balloon tamponade or TIPS

Reference: Sabinston Textbook of Surgery 21st Edition, SECTION X ABDOMEN, Chapter 54, The Liver Pg: 1445.

questions.text: Which among the following ligaments is attached on the diaphragmatic surface of the spleen?
questions.solution:
• Spleen is an intraperitoneal organ and is suspended in the peritoneal cavity by multiple peritoneal reflections misreferred to as 'ligaments'; at the diaphragmatic surface is the splenophrenic ligament, the visceral surface, and the gastrosplenic, splenorenal, and splenocolic ligaments.
  • In patients without portal hypertension, the splenophrenic and splenocolic ligaments are relatively avascular.
  • The gastrosplenic ligament carries the short gastric vessels in its superior aspect and the left gastroepiploic in its inferior aspect.
  • The splenorenal ligament houses the splenic artery and vein as well as the tail of the pancreas. The tail of the pancreas abuts the splenic hilum in 30% of individuals and is within 1 cm of the hilum in 70% of cases, thus it is important to ligate the splenic vessels within 1 cm from the splenic hilum to avoid injury to the tail of the pancreas.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 70, The Spleen, Pg: 1220.

choices.text: Polycystin-1 and polycystin-2 play a critical role
Visible haematuria occurs in up to 40% of patients with ADPKD
Hypertension is the least common manifestation of ADPKD

questions.text: Not true regarding ADPKD?
questions.solution:
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)-

  • Due to mutations in Polycystin-1 (chromosome 16) and polycystin-2 (chromosome 4).

Features -

  • Renal size increases with age resulting in a flank or abdominal mass in some patients.
  • Cysts contain clear fluid, thick brown material or coagulated blood.
  • Visible haematuria occurs in up to 40% of patients with ADPKD.
  • Cyst haemorrhage is a frequent complication with or without haematuria, depending on whether the cyst communicates with the collecting system or not.
  • Hypertension is the most common manifestation of ADPKD and a major contributor to renal disease progression and cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.
  • After the age of 20 years, most patients are hypertensive.
  • Associated with intracranial aneurysms in 10% of cases.

VHL disease is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that is characterised by multiple pathologies, including clear-cell RCC (ccRCC), pheochromocytoma, retinal angiomas and haemangioblastomas of the brainstem, cerebellum or spinal cord.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1482.

questions.text: All of the following are causes for vesico-vaginal fistula, except?
questions.solution:
Anterior colporrhaphy can lead to formation of vesicovaginal fistula.

Causes of vesicovaginal fistula include -

  • Obstetric- Protracted or neglected labour.
  • Gynaecological- Total hysterectomy and anterior colporrhaphy.
  • Radiotherapy.
  • Direct neoplastic infiltration. Exceptionally, carcinoma of the cervix ulcerates through the anterior fornix to implicate the bladder.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The Urinary Bladder, Pg: 1505.

questions.text: Which zone of the prostate suggested by McNeal gives rise to carcinoma most commonly?
questions.solution:
The classification of the prostate into different zones by McNeal -

  • Peripheral zone - Lies mainly posteriorly and from which most carcinomas arise.
  • Central zone - Lies posterior to the urethral lumen and above the ejaculatory ducts as they pass through the prostate; the two zones are rather like an egg in an eggcup.
  • Transitional zone - Periurethral in location. Most cases of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) arise from this zone.

MC NEAL ZONE OF ANATOMY OF PROSTATE

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 27th Edition, Chapter 78, The prostate and seminal vesicles, Pg: 1456.

questions.text: A young male patient had urethral injury after road traffic accident. Following procedure has been performed. What is the likely procedure?
questions.solution:
(a)Percutaneous puncture of the bladder with passage of a guidewire into the bladder followed by dilatation of the track over the guidewire.

(b)Thereby allowing placement of a catheter into the bladder.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The urinary bladder, Pg: 1509.

questions.text: Most commonly bypassed artery during CABG
questions.solution:
• The left main coronary artery, which arises from the aortic root, can be the site of significant stenosis ('left main stem disease') and carries the worst prognosis in terms of survival without surgery.
  • The artery is inaccessible at its origin and therefore grafts are anastomosed to its branches, the left anterior ascending artery (LAD) or anterior interventricular artery and obtuse/marginal (OM) branches of the circumflex artery.
  • The LAD is the most frequently diseased coronary artery and most often bypassed during CABG surgery.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 59, Cardiac Surgery, Pg: 947.

questions.text: Identify device shown in below image
questions.solution:
Vacuum-assisted closure

  • The use of negative pressure applied to a tissue defect has positive effects on wound closure, as well as making difficult and complex wounds more manageable during the early stages of granulation.
  • Exudate is removed and the suction pressure affects angiogenesis and tissue regeneration. The technique can be applied as part of early wound management before definitive surgical closure has been planned, or in some cases to avoid the need for surgery altogether. The foam sponge dressing is connected by a tube to a negative pressure pump that can be controlled to give intermittent suction

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery

choices.text: Split-thickness skin graft can be expand from ratio of 1:1.5 to 1:6
Most used donor site is thigh
Vascularisation is not needed for graft take on a bed
Graft failure commonly caused by pus, exudates or residual dead tissue beneath the skin

questions.text: All are the following statements are correct regarding split thickness skin graft except?
questions.solution:
Split-thickness skin grafts

  • Split-thickness skin grafts are taken with either hand-held or powered skin knives.

The most used donor site is the thigh, with the buttock preferable in children and cosmetically sensitive individuals. For larger grafts, almost any flat surface can be harvested, including the scalp if shaved (a very good and useful donor site).

  • The thickness of the graft harvested, ease of graft ‘take’ and donor site healing must be weighed against the lack of durability of thin split-thickness skin grafts.
  • Split grafts can be perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’; they can be further meshed to allow expansion.
  • This is carried out on a device that cuts a series of slits along the skin, allowing it to expand from a ratio of anything from 1:1.5 to about 1:6.
  • Grafts will only take on a bed on which they can become vascularised. Preparation of the wound bed is therefore an essential part of a successful graft.
  • Graft failure is commonly caused by pus, exudate or residual dead tissue beneath the skin, haematoma or shearing forces. A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage success.

Split-thickness skin grafts consist of epidermis and a variable amount of dermis and are sometimes referred to as Thiersch grafts. They are commonly harvested from the thigh using a dermatome or graft knife to achieve a consistent depth. It is relatively simple to harvest large areas of skin to reconstruct sizeable defects such as those following a significant burn injury

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 47, Plastic and reconstructive surgery, Pg: 686

choices.text: Coins are most frequently swallowed object in children
Ingested magnets can cause entero-enteric fistula
Button Batteries in esophagus should not be removed
Batteries in stomach are either removed urgently or followed very closely with repeat X-rays

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding swallowed foreign bodies except?
questions.solution:
• Coins are the most frequently swallowed foreign bodies in children. Once beyond the cardia, they are usually passed in a few days.
  • A plain radiograph of the abdomen, chest and neck should establish the site of radio-opaque objects. Oesophageal objects can be removed endoscopically under general anaesthesia.
  • Button batteries must be removed within hours because if they remain in the oesophagus they can perforate into the trachea or aorta. Batteries in the stomach are either removed urgently or followed very closely with repeat x-rays over a couple of days.
  • The need to remove sharp objects depends on their size, the age of the child and their position in the gut. Ingested magnets can cause entero-enteric fistulae when they fix to one another in adjacent loops of bowel. Battery ingestion in older children and young people may be a manifestation of self-harm.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery, 27th edition, Page -132

questions.text: Which among the following syndrome is caused by the mutation in the STK 11 gene?
questions.solution:
Peutz- Jeghers syndrome-

  • Caused by a mutation in STK11 gene on chromosome 19.
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance

Clinical features -

  • Hyperpigmentation of buccal mucosa and lips.
  • Hamartomatous polyps throughout the GI tract.
  • Increased risk of cancers (colorectal, stomach, breast).

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter: 12, pg: 202

questions.text: Most common feature of MEN 1
questions.solution:
• PHPT is the most common feature of MEN1, occurring in more than 90% of patients, and it is the experience of these authors that all patients with MEN1 have PHPT.
  • Like sporadic PHPT, patients may have asymptomatic disease, osteoporosis, nephrolithiasis, or symptoms including fatigue, malaise, polyuria, polydipsia, and constipation.
  • The diagnosis is made biochemically with an elevated calcium and an inappropriately nonsuppressed parathyroid hormone (PTH) level.
  • Compared to sporadic cases, PHPT occurs in the setting of MEN1 at an earlier age (20-25 years vs. 55 years) and an equal female : male ratio (1:1 vs. 3:1).

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, CHAPTER 57, The adrenal glands and other abdominal endocrine disorders, Pg:912.

choices.text: MRI is first line of investigation
In communicating hydrocephalus, LP can confirm raised CSF pressure
Pseudotumor cerebri results in symptomatic raised CSF pressure without ventricular enlargement
NPH is potential reversible cause of dementia

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding hydrocephalus except
questions.solution:
CT is the first line of investigation for hydrocephalus.

Option B - In communicating hydrocephalus, lumbar puncture can confirm the raised CSF pressure and also relieve it temporarily.

Option C - Idiopathic intracranial hypertension or pseudotumor cerebri results in symptomatic raised CSF pressure without ventricular enlargement. CSF diversion may be necessary to prevent permanent visual loss.

Option D - NPH is a potentially reversible cause of dementia.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 704.

questions.text: Which among the following terminologies denotes the transplant of graft between different species?
questions.solution:
Xenograft is a graft performed between different species.

Some common terminology in organ transplantation include -

  • Allograft - An organ or tissue transplanted from one individual to another.
  • Xenograft - A graft performed between different species.
  • Orthotopic graft - A graft placed in its normal anatomical site.
  • Heterotopic graft - A graft placed in a site different from that where the organ is normally located.
  • Alloantigen - Transplant antigen.
  • Alloantibody -Transplant antibodies.
  • HLA (Human Leukocyte Antigen) - The main trigger to graft rejection.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 27th Edition, Chapter 82, Transplantation, Pg: 1533.
